posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked:
We have been having issues with odometry. It tends to undershoot despite us triple-checking the values. This undershooter seems to be somewhat inconsistent at times. For example, we have a path planner path that picks up the note perfectly fine but is a good 4 feet off from its firing spot on return. The strangest behavior is that this is very noticeable when moving quickly but better when moving slowly.

Technically we are using a pose estimator but we are not passing in vision values.

I can provide code samples if needed

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.custom_user_title: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: Marcus Kauffman
posts.cooked:
What motors/drive encoders are you using?

Have you checked your wheel diameter (nominal diameter can be >5mm off)? What drivetrain are you using.

Code would be helpful

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
dragonblade316:

issues with odometry

You didn’t say how you know the odometry is off. If it’s failure to follow a PathPlanner path that’s a lot different than the odometry doesn’t reflect where the robot is on the field. The easiest check that I know is watch the robot move live in AdvantageScope to get insight into where things are going wrong. You do have to get the right pose “units” into AS and there is a difference between using Pose2D and Pose3D.

posts.name: mandrews281
posts.cooked:
Also remember if you’re driving hard, you’re more likely to generate wheel slip which will throw off the odometry.  You also don’t mention what drive train you are using (tank, mecanum, swerve).

MA

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked:
dragonblade316:

The strangest behavior is that this is very noticeable when moving quickly but better when moving slowly

This sounds like your robot’s wheels are slipping. That happens when your wheels accelerate too quickly and the force applied by the motors exceeds the force of friction between the wheel surface and the carpet. You can pass commanded wheel speeds through a SlewRateLimiter to limit the acceleration and reduce slip.

AprilTag measurements can be used to correct for odometry errors if you have a vision system (like a limelight or photonvision) and AprilTags set up in your work space

posts.name: Matt Pizzimenti
posts.cooked:
We had similar issues, and part of it was definitely wheel slip (as mentioned above), but the other part was having un-tuned AutoBuilder PID values. This can cause accidental over-steering in particular.

You can see this directly in PathPlanner under the Telemetry view. You might need to add your robot IP address in your PathPlanner settings (10.TE. AM .2) to enable the telemetry tab to connect. Once you connect to telemetry in PathPlanner, you can run your auto and watch the robot follow its path. Pay attention to the velocity and rotation graphs: if the actual rotation or velocity overshoots (or undershoots) the commanded rotation or velocity, you need to tune the relevant PID constants to get those lines closer together on the graph.

The PID constants should be in your AutoBuilder constructor, wherever you declared that (probably in your Drivetrain code). I’m not a PID expert, but our team figured out basic improvements using the WPILib PID tutorials.

We also reduced our acceleration to avoid wheel slip; more recently, we switched to higher-friction tread so we can speed things up without introducing slip again.

Hope this all helps! Auto tuning has been a multi-year journey for us, and we’re still learning too

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked:
We have done basic tuning (but not well). We are decently sure are issues are largely odom since it gets very off in advantagescope.

@mandrews281 How much is a robot likely to slip in auto in a worst-case scenario?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.custom_user_title: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
dragonblade316:

very off

This is a qualitative measure of a quantitative problem. Combine all of the responses in this thread and you know how to see exactly how much is the deviation at what points in the path and what the robot is doing and supposed to be doing at those points.

Is it slipping because of straight-line acceleration or failure to track well on turns? Is the robot touching the stage with the wheels spinning to get that Note? Measure all this and you likely will see the cause and solution and if not, others will help without having to guess.
